Mongiardo,Reinsch in S.C. Runoff
Jim Mongiardo and Bill Reinsch meet in the second
day of voting in a runoff election today for the office of
Student Council president. The runoff was necessitated
after Mongiardo and Reinsch finished one-two in the
three man race last Wednesday.
Sandy Cohn was low man with 161 votes. Reinsch
polled 284 and Mongiardo captured 286 of the total
731 votes cast in two days of balloting. The turnout
was slightly less than half the undergraduate student

ing polls. The runoff balloting started yesterday and
will continue today. The result will be posted this
evening in the dorm mailroom.
Presidential candidate Bill Reinsch stated that "I
feel that the students should weigh the platforms of
both candidates, and vote for the candidate that has
the most to offer.
"My platform is to create an effective student voice
to the administration by graphically pointing out our
problems and showing that the students support the

problems faced by undergraduates that can be solved
by the Council. However, he must be a responsible
leader and he must bear in mind that he is the official
representative of the Student Body."
Corunenting on direct student action to solve problems. Mongiardo stated that "the Student Council, if
used properly, can be used to solve problems rather
than massive protest actions that tend to embarrass
the administration. A rational objection to administration policy will be acted on much quicker than an

By PETER KOPER
Vociferous right wing elements
marred civil rights leader Bayard
Rustin's speech at Levering Hall
last Sunday. The interruptions
by members of the Ku Klux Klan
and the National States Rights
Party culminated several days'
activities aimed against Rustin.

JOSEPH W. ALSO?
Alsop wrote a syndicated political column, "The Capitol Parade," from 1937 to 1940, and
from 1945 to 1958, he and his
brother, Stewart J. Alsop, coauthored the column "Matter of
Fact". The Alsop brothers have
also written two books, We Accuse and The Reporter's Trade.
During World War II, Mr.
Alsop served in the U.S. Navy
and the American Volunteer Air
Force. An aide to Gen. Clair
Chennault, he was captured by
the Japanese at Hong Kong and
held prisoner for nearly two
years. Upon release, he was appointed chief of the Lend Lease
Mission to Ching at Chunking.
Frank R. Kent, for whom the
lectureship was named, was managing editor of the Baltimore
Sun for ten years and served as
London correspondent glaring
the early Twenties.

political activity is a rewarding direction for their energies and interests. Johns Hopkins is fortunate in possessing a vital community of students who are politically
aware and vocal in their expression.
Nevertheless we have reached a time when one
group has allowed their zeal to take them beyond the
bounds of reason and decency.

Horne, distressed at the Hopkins platform offered
by civil rights leader Bayard Bustin, mimeographed the
public police record of Mr. Rustin's arrests involving
homosexual activities. He added a snatch of testimony
describing one such incident in lewd and purrient terms
and handed them door to door in the vicinity of 37th
Street and Keswick Avenue.
Iforne has stated that he distributed the material
because he was in opposition to the political theories of
Mr. Bustin. Horne takes exception to Rustin's views of
economic equalization and his alleged associated with
the forces of the left.
What all this has to do with a man's personal
psychological disorder is hard to determine. To attack
him in this manner is a far greater perversion than that
of Mr. Bustin.
Mr. Home's conduct only serves to discredit
Loth him and his opinions. Ile cannot, now, be a
legitimate member of the Hopkins political community.

Of Cabbages and Kings
It has been the policy of the New.4-1441er in recent years to regard the Student Council as an atrophied
limb of the student body, a condition which might be
best overcome by painless amputation. Failing in just
such an effort some three years ago, we have sat back
and watched the Council continue to function spasmodically and ineffectually, with annual presidential
elections providing no cure by which life and purposive
activity might be restored.
This year, however, a possibility for rejuvenation
exists. Bill Reinseh has accurately diagnosed the cause
of the Council's impotence as being the lethargy of its
members and their failure to employ novel and unusual
approaches in dealing with student affairs. Beinsch's
plan for the "exertion of positive pressure on the administration" through "orderly and organized student
action" exemplifies the type of attitude which the (ouncil must adopt if it ever hopes to attract student support
anti become a leader of student opinion on campus.
Jim Mongiardo, Reinsch's opponent, remains mired
in the muck of precedent. His platform expresses the
traditional disappointment in the Council's failure to
live up to its "tremendous potential as a positive representative body," and yet it can only attribute this situation to a lack of decorum at Council meetings. Focusing
excessively on organization, he shows little awareness
of the problems currently confronting Hopkins undergraduates, while Beinsch enumerates several, presenting
in addition concrete means of action.
The implications of today's vote are clear. Reinseh's
election would reflect students' justifiable resentment
against administration neglect and their potential desire to more overtly demonstrate their feelings. The
election of Mongiardo would indicate a mandate for the
current policy of non-directional Council activity. From
the sidelines, it appears to be no contest.

mission; rather, sum violations
should be within the province of
the office of the Dean of Students, to be handled as he sees
fit, either by himsok or by the

It would seem, then, that the
logical course for the Honor
Commission to have followed
would have been to ask the administration to make a unilateral statement, or else to refer
the matter to the Student Council — the proper student organization to make the policy — for
action.
As it now stands, since possession of an unregistered key
is not an overt attempt at unfair academic advantage, (Honor
Commission members speak
piously of the difference between
intent and attempt, but have
apparently conveniently forgotten the distinction here), it is
not within the province of the
Honor Commission's constitutionally-permitted function. It
would thus seem necessary for
the recent "policy statement" to
be scrapped in favor of a constitutional amendment.
Living under the Honor System - requires a certain amount
of sacrifice and self-discipline
on the part of Hopkins undergraduates. There also exists a
corresponding obligaticn on the
part of the Honor Commission
to keep its part of the bargain,
operate within its constitutionally-defined bounds, and not
violate the trust placed in It
by the student body. Contrary
to what President Carpenter declares, the Honor Commission
and the Honor System need
student support; without it, the
entire concept is useless.
John M. Briekman
Senior member of the

To the Editors:
The criticism voiced in Mr.
Freedman's final editorial is as
close to the parting words of an
elder statesman as the NewsLetter is able to publish. It is
beneficial to be told that conditions are not the best, that
there are changes to be made,
and that the best efforts of a
few are not sufficient and cannot be substituted for the efforts
of all.
It is true that there does exist
a negative and apathetic attitude on this campus, and it does
not become a newspaper editor
to be modest in speaking out
against it. However, the remarks
concerning the President of the
University did not display much
consideration for the job of the
President and were not fair to
Milton S. Eisenhower.

The Presidency, since 1956,
has not been a static institution.
Assuming a position that was
left in a state of near-chaos, the
President went to work rebuilding a university that languished
in post-war decline. His work to
raise faculty salaries, erect
buildings, create departments,
and devise new programs is well
known. This is his job. It has
been executed with wisdom, vigor, and dignity.
It is true that these accomplishments do not "directly"
affect the undergraduate. It
might be too muth to expect the
president to eat lunch in the
snack bar or captain a faculty
intramural team. There are limits which a man may not exceed.
Does this mean, then, that he
does not participate actively in
student affairs?
The Committee of Special
Events and the programs which
it sponsors are the President's
own project. It is only at his

to demonstrate their scientific
abilities to parents, fellow students, and the public."

sciences — such as chemistry,
physics, and electricity—or the
earth sciences—such as plants,
animals, and health.
The first place winner in
Division I (grades 10, 11 and 12)
will win an all-expense paid trip
to the National Science Fair in
Dallas, Texas. Other awards,
ranging from $25 savings bonds
to $200 scholarships will be presented to second, third and

Frosh Batsmen Seen Tough
By JIM SLOAN
Sporting two fine pitchers and
a strong infield, Coach Dave
Blizzard's
freshinan baseball
beam kicks off what could turn
out to be a bright season.
The frosh roster is composed
of fifteen players, most of whom
saw quite a bit of action at their
respective high schools.
Pitching Staff
Leading the contingent is a
mound staff composed of Dave
Brainerd, Hal Thorne, and Dave
Verner. Brainerd, while co-captain of his high school team in
Chicago, posted an impressive
1.0 E.R.A. and averaged ten
strikeouts per game. Thorne has
a record of twelve wins against
four defeats during his last two
years of high school. He will
probably get the catching assignment when Brainerd does the
pitching. Verner, the third member of the staff, has been showing good progress and will be
an important back up man for
the two leading pitchers.
Strength in Outfield
Roy Pool from Princeton, New
Jersey, plays left field position;
while Tony Stone. a .300 hitter
in high school, is covering center field. There are several contenders vying for the starting
assignment in the right field spot.
Among them are Otis Abbot,
Dave Finley, Bill Harlow, Dave
Searles, Jeff Lobel, and Mike
Reymann.
Solid Infield
The infield looks solid for the
frosh this season. The first base
assignment is covered by Rich
Grayson from New York. Jim
Zuger, promising second baseman from Kansas City, should
be a strong asset to the team.
He sported a .300 hitting average in high school, and his speed

and quick hands add greatly to

the team's defensive potential.
The shortstop position is filled
by Dan Contest! from City College. Rounding out the infield is
Mike Avery, a strong hitter and
third baseman from Annapolis.

optimism in summing up the
season's outlook. He remarked,

by civil rights leader Bayard Bustin, mimeographed the
public police record of Mr. Rustin's arrests involving
homosexual activities. He added a snatch of testimony
describing one such incident in lewd and purrient terms
and handed them door to door in the vicinity of 37th

Iforne has stated that he distributed the material
because he was in opposition to the political theories of

economic equalization and his alleged associated with

Of Cabbages and Kings
It has been the policy of the New.4-1441er in recent years to regard the Student Council as an atrophied
limb of the student body, a condition which might be
best overcome by painless amputation. Failing in just
such an effort some three years ago, we have sat back
and watched the Council continue to function spasmodically and ineffectually, with annual presidential
elections providing no cure by which life and purposive
activity might be restored.
This year, however, a possibility for rejuvenation
exists. Bill Reinseh has accurately diagnosed the cause
of the Council's impotence as being the lethargy of its
members and their failure to employ novel and unusual
approaches in dealing with student affairs. Beinsch's
plan for the "exertion of positive pressure on the administration" through "orderly and organized student
action" exemplifies the type of attitude which the (ouncil must adopt if it ever hopes to attract student support
anti become a leader of student opinion on campus.
Jim Mongiardo, Reinsch's opponent, remains mired
in the muck of precedent. His platform expresses the
traditional disappointment in the Council's failure to
live up to its "tremendous potential as a positive representative body," and yet it can only attribute this situation to a lack of decorum at Council meetings. Focusing
excessively on organization, he shows little awareness
of the problems currently confronting Hopkins undergraduates, while Beinsch enumerates several, presenting
in addition concrete means of action.
The implications of today's vote are clear. Reinseh's
election would reflect students' justifiable resentment
against administration neglect and their potential desire to more overtly demonstrate their feelings. The
election of Mongiardo would indicate a mandate for the
current policy of non-directional Council activity. From
the sidelines, it appears to be no contest.

mission; rather, sum violations
should be within the province of
the office of the Dean of Students, to be handled as he sees
fit, either by himsok or by the
Student Council.
It would seem, then, that the
logical course for the Honor
Commission to have followed
would have been to ask the administration to make a unilateral statement, or else to refer
the matter to the Student Council — the proper student organization to make the policy — for
action.
As it now stands, since possession of an unregistered key
is not an overt attempt at unfair academic advantage, (Honor
Commission members speak
piously of the difference between
intent and attempt, but have
apparently conveniently forgotten the distinction here), it is
not within the province of the
Honor Commission's constitutionally-permitted function. It
would thus seem necessary for
the recent "policy statement" to
be scrapped in favor of a constitutional amendment.
Living under the Honor System - requires a certain amount
of sacrifice and self-discipline
on the part of Hopkins undergraduates. There also exists a
corresponding obligaticn on the
part of the Honor Commission
to keep its part of the bargain,
operate within its constitutionally-defined bounds, and not
violate the trust placed in It
by the student body. Contrary
to what President Carpenter declares, the Honor Commission
and the Honor System need
student support; without it, the
entire concept is useless.
John M. Briekman

To the Editors:
The criticism voiced in Mr.
Freedman's final editorial is as
close to the parting words of an
elder statesman as the NewsLetter is able to publish. It is
beneficial to be told that conditions are not the best, that
there are changes to be made,
and that the best efforts of a
few are not sufficient and cannot be substituted for the efforts
of all.
It is true that there does exist
a negative and apathetic attitude on this campus, and it does
not become a newspaper editor
to be modest in speaking out
against it. However, the remarks
concerning the President of the
University did not display much
consideration for the job of the
President and were not fair to
Milton S. Eisenhower.

The Presidency, since 1956,
has not been a static institution.
Assuming a position that was
left in a state of near-chaos, the
President went to work rebuilding a university that languished
in post-war decline. His work to
raise faculty salaries, erect
buildings, create departments,
and devise new programs is well
known. This is his job. It has
been executed with wisdom, vigor, and dignity.
It is true that these accomplishments do not "directly"
affect the undergraduate. It
might be too muth to expect the
president to eat lunch in the
snack bar or captain a faculty
intramural team. There are limits which a man may not exceed.
Does this mean, then, that he
does not participate actively in
student affairs?
The Committee of Special
Events and the programs which
it sponsors are the President's
own project. It is only at his

By JED P. LUCHOW
The fr: shman lacrosse team
got off to a tougher start than
expected.
Losing to the Virginia frosh
9-7, the game appeared closer
than this slight two goal difference indicates. The Virginia
stickers boasted Quayle and Norton, two strong middies, who lost
their eligibility at the end of
the game.
Stand Outs
Coach Wilson Fewster cited
defenseman Mike Clark and
goalie John Kelly for their out-

standing efforts. The defense, as
predicted, looked steady with
Cardillo proving that some stickers aren't afraid of contact.
Kelly made some fine saves and
looked real good on clears.
With pulled muscles and little
practice both Charlie Goodell
and Phil Buck showed they still
have the moves and the shots.
Bob Comisky, also on the first
midfield, showed another strong
shot when he could manage to
get it off.
Will Scroggs, leading the second midfield with Don Yablo-

nowitz and John Pell, showed
hussle. Scroggs was all over the
field," remarked Fewster, "but
with little help how far could
he go?"
Weak on attack, the Baby Jays
had to rely on the midfield for
the bulk of the scoring. Playmaker and feeder Jim Feely injured his foot early in the week
and will not see action for a
while.
Gorczyk, Pilachowski, and

City Science Fair
More than 150 students from
Junior and senior high schools
in Baltimore, Howard, Carroll,
and Harford Counties and Baltimore City will participate in the
eleventh Baltimore Science Fair,
sponsored by the Johns Hopkins
and Kiwanis Club of North Baltimore, April 1 and 2 in the
Athletic Center.
According to Mr. Paul Arnold,
Chairman of the Baltimore
Science Fair Committee, "The
Fair is an annual exhibition of
projects developed by individual
secondary school students interested in science. It is presented
to give young people the chance
to demonstrate their scientific
abilities to parents, fellow students, and the public."
The original projects will be
classified in either the physical
sciences — such as chemistry,
physics, and electricity—or the
earth sciences—such as plants,
animals, and health.
The first place winner in
Division I (grades 10, 11 and 12)
will win an all-expense paid trip
to the National Science Fair in
Dallas, Texas. Other awards,
ranging from $25 savings bonds
to $200 scholarships will be presented to second, third and
fourth place winners in both

Frosh Batsmen Seen Tough
By JIM SLOAN
Sporting two fine pitchers and
a strong infield, Coach Dave
Blizzard's
freshinan baseball
beam kicks off what could turn
out to be a bright season.
The frosh roster is composed
of fifteen players, most of whom
saw quite a bit of action at their
respective high schools.
Pitching Staff
Leading the contingent is a
mound staff composed of Dave
Brainerd, Hal Thorne, and Dave
Verner. Brainerd, while co-captain of his high school team in
Chicago, posted an impressive
1.0 E.R.A. and averaged ten
strikeouts per game. Thorne has
a record of twelve wins against
four defeats during his last two
years of high school. He will
probably get the catching assignment when Brainerd does the
pitching. Verner, the third member of the staff, has been showing good progress and will be
an important back up man for
the two leading pitchers.
Strength in Outfield
Roy Pool from Princeton, New
Jersey, plays left field position;
while Tony Stone. a .300 hitter
in high school, is covering center field. There are several contenders vying for the starting
assignment in the right field spot.
Among them are Otis Abbot,
Dave Finley, Bill Harlow, Dave
Searles, Jeff Lobel, and Mike
Reymann.
Solid Infield
The infield looks solid for the
frosh this season. The first base
assignment is covered by Rich
Grayson from New York. Jim
Zuger, promising second baseman from Kansas City, should
be a strong asset to the team.
He sported a .300 hitting average in high school, and his speed

and quick hands add greatly to

the team's defensive potential.
The shortstop position is filled
by Dan Contest! from City College. Rounding out the infield is
Mike Avery, a strong hitter and
third baseman from Annapolis.
The coach expressed hopeful
optimism in summing up the
season's outlook. He remarked,
